Award.AwardTitle: Coupled-physics imaging methods and geodesic X-ray transforms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving feature detection is a constant challenge in medical and geophysical imaging, with tremendous benefits to society such as the adequate monitoring of medical conditions or natural resources, and the imaging of previously "invisible" features. This project presents two approaches leading to such improvements. A first approach is the design and theoretical analysis of imaging methods exploiting physical phenomena in new ways, leading to imaging strategies with both improved contrast and resolution, and providing access to new features such as anisotropic properties of muscle fibers. A second approach is to provide distortion-free reconstructions and accurately located inclusions in human bodies or the Earth's crust. This is achieved by using more realistic descriptions (specifically, spatially varying) of the propagation speed of the waves used to probe the medium of interest. The model considered becomes augmented with new technicalities, where additional phenomena (e.g., caustics) can occur and open mathematical questions abound. The present project provides theoretical and practical imaging answers to some of these new problems.

This project focuses on the theoretical and mathematical understanding of: (i) coupled-physics inverse problems, which often consist of parameter identification problems in partial differential equations (PDE) using internal measurements; and (ii) geodesic X-ray transforms (a generalization of the famous Radon transform, in two dimensions), with applications to X-Ray Tomography in media with variable index of refraction. In the former topic, methods from analysis and PDEs are used to derive reconstruction algorithms for various models of increasing complexity, including additional constitutive parameters relevant for medical imaging, and including a transition from scalar to systems of PDEs. In the latter topic, the investigator uses tools of integral geometry, Fourier analysis, and PDEs to provide statements about injectivity/stability (or lack thereof), reconstruction formulas and their numerical validation, for the tensor tomography problem on Riemannian surfaces. Generalizations to higher dimensions, attenuated transforms and other types of flows (e.g., magnetic and thermostat flows) are also considered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Main goals: This project had two points of focus, with broad applications to the imaging sciences:

  1. Coupled-physics inverse problems, which consist here in the study of the reconstruction of coefficients of elliptic partial differential equations from internal functionals. For various problems which aim at reconstructing, for instance, conductive or elastic properties of a given body, one goal in mind is to produce reconstruction algorithms recovering these unknown properties from various kinds of measurements, and to provide numerical validation for these algorithms.
  2. The study of geodesic X-ray transforms, which consists in reconstructing a function (or more generally, a tensor field) from knowledge of its integrals along a family of geodesic curves. In this topic, some goals are, among others, to study the invertibility and ill-posedness of such problems, to study the impact of the underlying geometry on the qualitative features of the inverse problem considered, and to provide efficient reconstruction algorithms for what is reconstructible, including numerical validation.

Products: Article nomenclature refers to the list of references at the end of the report.

  • On the first topic, articles [1,2] were produced, providing mathematical footing for imaging methods aimed at obtaining information about anisotropic conductive [2], and anisotropic elastic [1] properties of materials. 
  • On the second topic, seven articles [3-9] were produced, providing mathematical analysis and numerical illustration of X-ray transforms for several imaging scenarios. In [3,4], explicit and efficiently implementable answers to the unattenuated and attenuated tensor tomography problems were provided in the case of the Euclidean unit disk. The works [5,6,7] are concerned with generalizations where a scalar attenuation [5,6] or a matrix-valued connection [7] is present in the transform, modelling further physical phenomena. For all these transforms, range characterizations and inversion formulas have been derived in the case of 'simple' Riemannian geometries. Geometries with infinite-length geodesics have been considered in [8], where inversion formulas could also be obtained. Finally in article [9], new sharp mapping properties for the geodesic X-ray transform were obtained, allowing for theoretically rigourous Uncertainty Quantification for X-ray transforms with noisy data.  

Dissemination: All articles have been published in top-tier Mathematics and Applied Mathematics journals. The works were disseminated through 25 presentations at international conferences and seminars at universities. The PI has also organized three minisymposia on the topics of the project. 

Undergraduate Participation: Four undergraduate students have been trained during this project, working on questions related to inverse problems and X-ray transforms. These projects have been instrumental in the pursuit, by two of them, of graduate studies in Mathematics and Applied Mathematics at top universities.

Benefits to society: In coupled-physics inverse problems, the PI’s results demonstrated the possibility of making visible certain anisotropic features in tissues (namely, conductive and elastic properties). This is a significant step toward the imaging of anisotropic structures (e.g., muscle fibers) and the detection of their defects. The work on integral geometry provides the possibility of imaging unknown properties in media with variable index of refraction, allowing non-trivial geometries of propagation, and a significant step toward making models more accurate in X-ray imaging.

Numerical packages: Numerical proof-of-concept simulations have been included in several of the works, and some of the codes developed along the way are currently available on the PI’s website. Such packages can simulate cases which are not fully theoretically understood, and as such may provide key insights on open problems through simulations.

References: 

  1. G.Bal, F.M., and G.Uhlmann. Reconstruction of a fully anisotropic elasticity tensor from knowledge of displacement fields. SIAM J. Appl. Math., 75(5):2214–2231, 2015
  2. F.M. and D.Rim. Imaging of isotropic and anisotropic conductivities from power densities in three dimensions. Inverse Problems, 34(7):075005, 2018.
  3. F.M. Efficient tensor tomography in fan-beam coordinates. Inverse Probl. Imaging, 10(2):433–459, May 2016.
  4. F.M. Efficient tensor tomography in fan-beam coordinates. II: attenuated transforms. Inverse Problems and Imaging, 12(2):433–460, 2018.
  5. Y.M.Assylbekov, F.M., and G.Uhlmann. Inversion formulas and range characterizations for the attenuated geodesic ray transform. Journal de Mathematiques Pures et Appliquees, 111:161–190, 2018
  6. F.M. and G.P.Paternain. The geodesic X-ray transform with a GL(n,C)-connection. Journal of Geometric Analysis (online), 2017. arXiv:1610.09571.
  7. F.M. Inversion of the attenuated geodesic X-ray transform over functions and vector fields on simple surfaces. SIAM J. Math. Anal., 48(2):1155–1177, 2016.
  8. C.Guillarmou and F.M.  Reconstruction formulas for x-ray transforms in negative curvature. Annales Inst. Fourier, 67(4):1353–1392, 2017.
  9. F.M., R.Nickl and G.P.Paternain. Efficient nonparametric Bayesian inference for X-ray transforms. The Annals of Statistics, 47(2):1113–1147, 2019.
